awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Regenerative Freeze Suppression for Thermally Bound Energy Storage Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project includes peak demand relief for utilities, reduced
freezer operating costs for retail stores, and natural refrigerants for regulators. Unfortunately, no state-ofthe-
art system simultaneously addresses all these issues. Industrial/commercial batteries remain
unaffordable, refrigeration costs account for 60% of a retail store?s electricity bills and equipment
manufacturers are only realizing incremental efficiency improvements with new vapor compression
architectures. This project introduces an energy storage technology, embedded in a natural refrigerant
cooling cycle, that provides load-shifting services and a 40% reduction in commercial freezer electrical
purchases. More importantly, it achieves this at a 3-year payback without government incentives using
natural, near ambient, materials.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will investigate an energy storage
technique utilizing water as the storage material in a time delayed, freeze-point-suppression refrigeration
cycle. The project will focus on the internal testing, third party validation and commercial demonstration
of a 10kWth system. Successful integration within low temperature refrigeration architectures requires
industrial design focused on skid/waste heat integration, validation testing to inform required part count
reductions/system revisions and demonstration to monitor, learn and revise the technology in preparation
for scale up.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

This NSF project increased the state-of-the-art understanding of thermodynamics and heat pumps. The project showed the viability of freeze point suppression cycles and highlighted the fallacy of humanities current overreliance on gas-phase thermodynamic cycles. Furthermore, the project pushed the boundary of many component level fundamentals including: surface chemistry, controls, multi-phase heat transfer, thermodynamic state point modeling, membrane separation, thermal separation, and heat pump separation.

 

The project?s overarching intellectual merit and contribution is the introduction of a new style of thermodynamic cycle that uses chemical composition and liquid-solid working fluids to achieve high levels of flexibility that customers can use to valuable ends. This project focused on the production of one such cycle type, called a Freeze Point Suppression Cycle. This cycle uses ice and a freeze point suppressant to produce useful cooling. Because these cycle types use only solids and liquids, their working fluids are readily storable and thus can isolate when energy is put into the cycle from when useful cooling is provided. This feature is exceptionally valuable in an age when A) customers want on-demand cooling bursts and B) the energy grid is struggling to maintain reliable power delivery.

 

In addition to bringing this entirely new branch of thermodynamics into the mainstream and proving its technical viability, this project also advanced several other fields from theory to lab setting to commercial settings. An example is the first known implementation of a hydrophobic multi-phase ice maker at an industrial facility. This project showed the value of such an ice maker and demonstrated its reliable operation in harsh industrial settings. This example is just one of many instances where the NSF funded work taken from the lab to real world implementation.

 

Broader Impacts:

Humanity faces an energy storage crisis that has not yet been fully realized. Currently, wind energy is the cheapest source of energy on earth, even without government subsidies. Solar PV is following close behind. Both of these energy sources will cause a dramatic de-stabilization of the energy grid without an appropriate amount of energy storage being deployed to support them.

 

The leading technology currently being deployed to meet this need is Li-ion batteries at a cost of roughly $400/kWh according to the Energy Information Agency. This cost is far too high to provide the storage required to curb the impact of wind and solar on the grid. Worse yet, the short life of Li-ion batteries has a significant detrimental effect on life costs and payback.

 

Freeze point suppression cycles, on the other hand, have a storage cost to the utility of roughly $40/kWh because their storage is embedded in the larger context of providing refrigeration to the customer. In other words, the customer pays for a refrigerator and gets the energy storage automatically, at a very low cost. The customer is willing to pay for a cost competitive refrigerator and pleasantly surprised that it also adds value as a battery.

 

The implications of this technology are far reaching. If deployed across Industrial, Commercial, and HVAC sectors it could supply 468 GWH and 120GW of long-term diurnal energy storage by 2050.

 

This energy storage, along with the inherent efficiency of the cycle, leads to a significant corresponding impact of greenhouse gas mitigation. By 2050, the technology would reduce total greenhouse gas emissions by 865 million metric tons per year.

 


Last Modified: 04/19/2019
Modified by: Russell Muren

Images (1 of )
  • The first commercial pilot of a freeze point suppression cycle developed during the phase II project capable of providing 34,000W of cooling.
    Kevin Davis

    Russell Muren
    NSF Phase II Demonstration Unit
  • the first freeze point suppression cycle developed during the Phase I project capable of supplying 200W of cooling
    Russell Muren
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Russell Muren
    NSF Phase I System
  • Example of typical freeze point suppression costs with no storage and not equipped with storage. The plot illustrates the fundamental merit of an embedded storage approach.
    Russell Muren
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Russell Muren
    Embedded Thermal Storage Benefits
